unnormalised: **Donating? Think Twice (Unless You're Super Rich, Yaar!)**
normalised: Donating? Think Twice (Unless You're Super Rich, Yaar!)

unnormalised: So, you've got that warm, fuzzy feeling and want to donate to charity, eh? Good on you! But before you empty your wallet faster than you can say "inflation," let's talk about the real cost, both in Rupees (₹) and in potential samosas you'll have to forgo. Remember that ₹500 note you were eyeing for that delicious butter chicken? Well, that's gone now. *Poof!* Disappeared into the ether, possibly buying someone a single bandage or a half-eaten biscuit. Okay, maybe not *that* bad. But still, think of the butter chicken!
normalised: So, you've got that warm, fuzzy feeling and want to donate to charity, eh? Good on you! But before you empty your wallet faster than you can say "inflation," let's talk about the real cost, both in rupees and in potential samosas you'll have to forgo. Remember that five hundred rupee note you were eyeing for that delicious butter chicken? Well, that's gone now. Poof! Disappeared into the ether, possibly buying someone a single bandage or a half-eaten biscuit. Okay, maybe not that bad. But still, think of the butter chicken!

unnormalised: Seriously though, charity is noble, but sometimes it feels like you're throwing ₹2000 notes into a black hole. You see those ads promising to build a school for the price of your monthly chai bill? Yeah, right! My chai bill is already the size of a small car payment. And those donation boxes outside malls, practically begging you to part with your hard-earned ₹10 coins? It's like they're saying, "Hey, we know you just blew ₹5000 on that fancy kurta, but surely you can spare a little change for the less fortunate, huh?" The guilt is real, folks, the guilt is *real*.
normalised: Seriously though, charity is noble, but sometimes it feels like you're throwing two thousand rupee notes into a black hole. You see those ads promising to build a school for the price of your monthly chai bill? Yeah, right! My chai bill is already the size of a small car payment. And those donation boxes outside malls, practically begging you to part with your hard-earned ten rupee coins? It's like they're saying, "Hey, we know you just blew five thousand rupees on that fancy kurta, but surely you can spare a little change for the less fortunate, huh?" The guilt is real, folks, the guilt is real.

unnormalised: Of course, some charities are legit. They actually do good work, use your ₹100 wisely, and don't just buy the director a new BMW. (Allegedly!) The problem is figuring out which ones are which. It's like navigating a Delhi market on a Sunday – chaotic, overwhelming, and you're probably going to get ripped off at least once. You might end up donating to a charity that spends 90% of its funds on "administrative costs," which is code for "office parties and imported cheese."

unnormalised: Then there's the whole "tax deduction" angle. Ah, the sweet relief of lowering your taxable income! But even that's a bit of a joke, isn't it? You donate ₹5000, get a tiny deduction, and then the government raises taxes on petrol by ₹5 per liter to make up for it. It's a zero-sum game, my friends! You're basically donating to the government disguised as a charity.

unnormalised: So, donate if you want, if your heart (and wallet) can handle it. Just remember to do your research, avoid the guilt trips, and always, *always* factor in the lost samosa potential. After all, a full tummy can also make the world a better place, right? And if all else fails, just give a ₹50 note to that poor chap at the traffic signal. At least you know *he'll* appreciate it (and probably buy himself some chai!).
